Detailed Description

Offers methods to use the Conjugate Gradients algorithm for the optimization of models.

As usual with other quasi-Newton methods, the error function is optimized by line searches, but here a special method is used to avoid bad performance that can occurr when using simple successive gradient vectors.
When performing a line search from point along direction , where the error minimum along this search path lies at it holds (using the line search definitions):

Looking at the gradient it follows:

which gives

Thus, the gradient at the new minimum is orthogonal to the previous search direction. If one now chooses successive search directions to be the local (negative) gradient directions, this can lead to the search point oscillating on these successive steps while making only little progress towards the minimum - the minimization proceeds very slowly.
A solution is to choose the next search direction such that, along this new direction, we retain the property that the component of the gradient parallel to the previous search direction remains zero (to lowest order):

When expanding to first order in , we finally obtain:

where is the Hessian matrix evaluated at point .
Search directions which satisfy this equation are said to be conjugate. For the evaluation of the search directions for quadratic target functions, the Polak-Ribiï¿½e formula is used:

Because of the fact, that usually the target function is not quadratic and line search is not exact, unwished search directions can be calculated. So the algorithm can be restarted during optimization with the search direction set to the current negative gradient.

For a more detailed description of this algorithm please refer to "Neural Networks for Pattern Recognition" by Christopher M. Bishop.

Author:
C. Igel
Date:
1999

Definition at line 168 of file CG.h.

Member Enumeration Documentation

enum CG::LineSearch

Used to specify the type of line search algorithm that is used by the CG algorithm:
"Linmin" is the original line search algorithm, "DLinmin" is a line search algorithm that additionally uses derivative information and "Cblnsrch" is a cubic line search.

Enumerator:
Dlinmin 
Linmin 
Cblnsrch 

Definition at line 178 of file CG.h.

Member Function Documentation

void CG::cg ( const Array< double > &  in,
const Array< double > &  target 
) [inline]

Updates the weights of the network by using the CG optimization algorithm.

The given input patterns in and their corresponding target values target are used to calculate the error of the currently used model. The resulting error function is then minimized by the BFGS algorithm, the weights of the network are updated.
Notice: Method initCG must be called before using the CG algorithm itself.

Parameters:
in Input patterns for the currently used model.
target Target values corresponding to the input patterns.
Returns:
none
Author:
C. Igel
Date:
1999
Changes
none
Status
stable

void CG::cg ( const Array< double > &  in,
const Array< double > &  target,
double &  fret 
)

Updates the weights of the network by using the CG optimization algorithm and returns the minimum value by reference.

The given input patterns in and their corresponding target values target are used to calculate the error of the currently used model. The resulting error function is then minimized by the CG algorithm, the weights of the network are updated.
Notice: Method initCG must be called before using the CG algorithm itself.

Parameters:
in Input patterns for the currently used model.
target Target values corresponding to the input patterns.
fret Minimum value of the error function.
Returns:
none
Author:
C. Igel
Date:
1999
Changes
none
Status

void CG::initCG ( const Array< double > &  in,
const Array< double > &  target,
LineSearch  ls,
int  reset = -1,
double  ax = 0.,
double  bx = 1.,
double  lambda = .25,
bool  verbose = false 
)

Initializes some internal variables used by the CG algorithm.

The given parameters are used to initialize some variables used by the CG and the line search algorithms and to allocate memory for internal structures.

Parameters:
in Input patterns for the currently used model.
target Target values corresponding to the input patterns.
ls Type of LineSearch algorithm, that is used by the BFGS algorithm. Possible values: "Dlinmin" (default value), "Linmin", "Cblnsrch"
reset No. of iterations that will be performed before a reset of the algorithm takes place. A reset is sometimes necessary because often the line minimization has not finished after "no. of parameters" iterations. If set to "-1" (default value), then the algorithm will be reset after iterations, where is the weight vector (including the bias).
ax Initial left bracket for the line search algorithms, the default bracket is "0".
bx Initial right bracket for the line search algorithms, the default bracket is "1".
lambda The initial value for the searched , that will minimize the function used by the line search algorithm. The default value is "0.25".
verbose If set to "true", a message will displayed when the CG algorithm performs a reset.
Returns:
none
Author:
C. Igel
Date:
1999
Changes
2002-01-16, ra:
Removed parameters "eps" and "ftol", because they are not used.
Status
stable
